snippet: After a spill greater than previously estimated, hundreds of thousands of people may have to wait days before the water is declared safe again.
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of residents of West Virginia are facing third day without water because of chemical spill in Elk River; officials report that thousands more toxic gallons leaked into river than was initially believed and that it may take days more before it is safe to drink water again.

byline.original: By DANIEL HEYMAN and EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS
byline.contributor: Daniel Heyman reported from Charleston, and Emma G. Fitzsimmons from New York. Ashley Southall contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: After a spill greater than previously estimated, hundreds of thousands of people may have to wait days before the water is declared safe again.

headline.main: Wait Continues for Safe Tap Water in West Virginia
headline.print_headline: The Wait Continues For Safe Tap Water In West Virginia
